item.title: One gene reveals clues to why humans thrived and Neanderthals didn’t
item.description: An international team of researchers scrutinized a version of a gene, ubiquitous in humans today, that is not present in Neanderthals or Denisovans — the hominins that lived alongside our ancestors. Their findings suggest tiny changes in brain chemistry could trigger behavioral change that sets us apart from Neanderthals.

item.title: Rep. Nancy Mace, a Trump critic turned ally, announces run for South Carolina governor

It’s unclear whether President Donald Trump will make an endorsement in the primary.

item.title: In beloved national parks, deep concern among Americans of all political persuasions
item.description: To see how the parks are faring amid the turmoil of the federal government’s downsizing, Washington Post reporters visited four locations just before peak summer season. We found that changes so far were subtle, though staff members cautioned that issues might emerge in coming months. We also found profound affection for America’s “crown jewels” — as the national parks have historically been described — strong support for their protection, and vivid concern over what budget and staffing cuts will mean in the years to come.

item.title: Smithsonian says it will restore information about Trump’s two impeachments to museum exhibit in coming weeks
item.description: The announcement came two days after the Smithsonian said it had removed Donald Trump’s name from the exhibits about presidential impeachments at the National Museum of American History. The Washington Post reported on Thursday that in July the museum removed a temporary placard describing Trump's impeachments and reverted the exhibit to how it looked in 2008.

item.title: Smithsonian removes mentions of Trump's two impeachments from National Museum of American History
item.description: A temporary placard, on display since 2021, described the president's historic impeachments. The Smithsonian said it restored the exhibition to an earlier version, which notes that “only three presidents have seriously faced removal.”

item.title: Air traffic control tower failed to warn passenger jet of Black Hawk’s path toward the plane before D.C. crash, FAA testifies
item.description: It was the agency’s first acknowledgement of a possible error in the Reagan National Airport control tower immediately before the fatal collision. The admission came during a National Transportation Safety Board hearing that featured testimony about a high number of takeoffs and landings at the airport, combined with heavy helicopter traffic, that led to air traffic controllers “pushing the line” on safety, in the words of a tower manager.

item.title: Trump plans to overhaul the East Wing to build a $200 million ballroom, one of the biggest changes to the White House in a century
item.description: The project, long on President Donald Trump’s wishlist, seeks to solve a problem his press secretary says has frustrated multiple U.S. presidents: a lack of indoor space for major functions. The White House State Ballroom will seat 650 people, more than triple the capacity of the East Room.

item.title: ‘Welcome to hell’: Former detainees describe beatings and sexual assault at the megaprison where the U.S. deported migrants
item.description: Interviews with 16 former detainees of El Salvador’s Terrorism Confinement Center offer the most complete view yet of conditions at the notorious prison. The Venezuelans, rounded up in President Donald Trump’s mass deportation campaign, told The Washington Post they were subjected to repeated beatings that left them bruised, bleeding or injured.

item.description: The National Weather Service has issued both severe thunderstorm and flood watches for the area. It says storms could produce torrential rain capable of producing “significant” flash flooding and damaging wind gusts.

item.title: Ukraine adopts new anti-corruption law as protests force Zelensky to retreat
item.description: The Ukrainian parliament restored the independence of the country’s two main anti-corruption bodies Thursday, just a week after voting to put them under the control of the attorney general, an ally of President Volodymyr Zelensky. Critics had said the previous law would neutralize them and jeopardize the country’s bid to join the European Union. Zelensky quickly signed the new measure.
